downloadJSAtOnload;\n\t\t\t}\n\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>\n\t\t\tDeferJS(\"https://d1bxh8uas1mnw7.cloudfront.net/assets/embed.js\");\n\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>\n\t\t\tDeferJS(\"https://d1bxh8uas1mnw7.cloudfront.net/assets/embed.js\");\n\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>\n I have amended it to turn of JS on all IE browsers less than 10.\n\t\tThis is due to a function in the iop.jquery.toolbar line 35/36. Uses .remove which is not native js supported in IE9 or lower */\n\t\t/*if('querySelector' in document\n\t\t&& 'localStorage' in window\n\t\t&& 'addEventListener' in window)*/\n\t\t\n\t\t/* This is the updated selector, taken from: https://justmarkup.com/log/2015/02/26/cut-the-mustard-revisited/ */\n\t\tif('visibilityState' in document) {\n\t\t\n\t\t/*! loadJS: load a JS. We are loading this command straight away, before the body loads, so that IF a user has JS enabled, their show hide panels will automatically be closed. */\n\t\t/* If this isn't here, then these panels appear open while the page is loading, then when the js loads at the bottom of the page, they are shut. So the users sees open content, then hidden after a second or 2 when the js is loaded. Not nice */\n\t\tdocument.write(\"<style>.reveal-content{display:none;}.search-res-filter .reveal-content{display:block;}</style>\");\n\t\t}\n\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>var __uzdbm_1 = \"3c1c769b-cc1f-4878-8c52-d7f85411c6e4\";var __uzdbm_2 = \"YWY0ZDYxNGUtODQyNy00ZTA2LTllYTctZGQ2NDJhYzFjMDVkJDE1NS4xMDEuMjYuNjY=\";</script> <script>(function(w, d, e, u, c, g, a, b){ w[\"SSJSConnectorObj\"] = {ss_cid : c, domain_info: \"auto\"}; a = d.createElement(e); a.async = true; a.src = u; b = d.getElementsByTagName(e)[0]; b.parentNode.insertBefore(a, b); })(window,document,\"script\",\"https://cdn.perfdrive.com/aperture/aperture.js\",\"a1c3\",\"ssConf\");</script></head>\n\t<body itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Organization\" class=\"issn-0004-637X\">\n    <a id=\"back-to-top-target\" tabindex=\"-1\"></a>\n    <!-- Google Tag Manager (noscript) -->\n<noscript><iframe src=\"https://www.googletagmanager.com/ns.html?id=GTM-M73Z4W\"\n    height=\"0\" width=\"0\" style=\"display:none;visibility:hidden\"></iframe></noscript>\n<!-- End Google Tag Manager (noscript) --><div class=\"cookies-banner-wrap\" id=\"cookieBanner\">\n    <div class=\"cookies-banner cf\">\n        This site uses cookies. <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">A Spectroscopic Survey of the Fields of 28 Strong Gravitational Lenses: Implications for <I>H</I> <SUB>0</SUB> </h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Michelle L. This includes author emails, affiliations, article published date, doi etc. -->\n\t<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 wd-jnl-art-article-info-wrapper\">\n      \t<div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n        \t<a id=\"wd-article-info-accordion\" href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide article information\">Article information</a>\n      \t</div>\n      \t<div class=\"reveal-content\">\n        \t<div class=\"article-meta\">\n          \t\t<!-- Start Affiliations --><div class=\"wd-jnl-art-author-affiliations\"><div class=\"replica-h4\">Author affiliations</div><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>1</sup>  Steward Observatory, University of Arizona, 933 North Cherry Avenue, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>2</sup>  Department of Physics and Astronomy, Rutgers University, 136 Frelinghuysen Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, USA</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>3</sup>   National Astronomical Observatory of Japan, 2-21-1 Osawa, Mitaka, Tokyo 181-8588, Japan</p><p class=\"mb-05\"><sup>4</sup>   Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica (ASIAA), P.O. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F850%2F1%2F94\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/850/1/94</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n             <P>Strong gravitational lensing provides an independent measurement of the Hubble parameter (<I>H</I> <SUB>0</SUB>). One remaining systematic is a bias from the additional mass due to a galaxy group at the lens redshift or along the sightline. We quantify this bias for more than 20 strong lenses that have well-sampled sightline mass distributions, focusing on the convergence <I>\u03ba</I> and shear <I>\u03b3</I>. In 23% of these fields, a lens group contributes \u22651% convergence bias; in 57%, there is a similarly significant line-of-sight group. For the nine time-delay lens systems, <I>H</I> <SUB>0</SUB> is overestimated by <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${11}_{-2}^{+3}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/apjaa9653ieqn1.gif\"></IMG>% on average when groups are ignored. In 67% of fields with total <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$\\kappa \\geqslant 0.01$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/apjaa9653ieqn2.gif\"></IMG>, line-of-sight groups contribute <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$\\gtrsim 2\\times $\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/apjaa9653ieqn3.gif\"></IMG> more convergence than do lens groups, indicating that the lens group is not the only important mass. Lens environment affects the ratio of four (quad) to two (double) image systems; all seven quads have lens groups while only 3 of 10 doubles do, and the highest convergences due to lens groups are in quads. We calibrate the <I>\u03b3</I>\u2013<I>\u03ba</I> relation: <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}})=(1.94\\pm 0.34)\\mathrm{log}({\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}})\\,+(1.31\\pm 0.49)$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/apjaa9653ieqn4.gif\"></IMG> with an rms scatter of 0.34 dex. Although shear can be measured directly from lensed images, unlike convergence, it can be a poor predictor of convergence; for 19% of our fields, <I>\u03ba</I> is <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"$\\gtrsim 2\\gamma $\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/apjaa9653ieqn5.gif\"></IMG>. Thus, accurate cosmology using strong gravitational lenses requires precise measurement and correction for all significant structures in each lens field.</P> </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/850/1/94&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa9653&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/850/1/94&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa9653&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017ApJ...850...94W\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2017ApJ...850...94W&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2017ApJ...850...94W\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653s1\" name=\"apjaa9653s1\">1.\u00a0Introduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Strong gravitational lensing has long been used to measure cosmological parameters, such as the Hubble constant, through measuring time delays for systems with quasar sources (Refsdal <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib100\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib100\">1964</a>; Schechter et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib104\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib104\">1997</a>; Keeton &amp; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib49\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib49\">1997</a>; Koopmans et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib58\">2003</a>; Saha et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib103\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib103\">2006</a>; Oguri <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib90\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib90\">2007</a>; Suyu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib109\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib109\">2010</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib110\">2013</a>; Rathna Kumar et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib98\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib98\">2015</a>; Birrer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib9\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib9\">2016</a>; Chen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib15\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib15\">2016</a>; Bonvin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib10\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib10\">2017</a>; Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib133\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib133\">2017</a>) and the dark energy density through determining statistical properties of strong lensing systems (Turner <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib117\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib117\">1990</a>; Chae <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib13\">2003</a>; Mitchell et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib76\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib76\">2005</a>; Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib94\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib94\">2008</a>). Lensed type Ia supernovae likewise can be used to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> (Refsdal <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib100\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib100\">1964</a>; Goldstein &amp; Nugent <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib32\">2017</a>), although few have yet been found (Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib53\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib53\">2015</a>; Goobar et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib33\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib33\">2017</a>). Future large surveys, such as those using the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) and <em>Euclid</em>, will discover a large sample (i.e., a few thousand) of lensed quasars that could then be used to statistically constrain these parameters to high precision (Oguri &amp; Marshall <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib92\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib92\">2010</a>; Laureijs et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib62\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib62\">2011</a>; Linder <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib65\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib65\">2011</a>; LSST Dark Energy Science Collaboration <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib66\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib66\">2012</a>).</p><p>Much of the work on galaxy-scale strong gravitational lenses has indicated that often the lens galaxy is not the only mass that significantly affects the lensing potential (e.g., Wallington et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib122\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib122\">1996</a>; Keeton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib50\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib50\">1997</a>; Claeskens et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib17\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib17\">2006</a>; Collett et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib20\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib20\">2013</a>). Since any mass along the line-of-sight (hereafter LOS) between the observer and the source can contribute to the lensing, any structure in which the lens galaxy might reside, as well as any unrelated structure sufficiently massive and close either in redshift or projected on the sky, might be important. In addition, the lens environment might affect the lensed image morphology (i.e., how many images of the source are present; Keeton &amp; Zabludoff <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib52\">2004</a>; Momcheva et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib77\">2006</a>).</p><p>Previous work has indicated that many galaxy-scale lenses are located in groups or clusters and/or in fields with projected LOS structures (e.g., Kundic et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib60\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib60\">1997</a>; Fassnacht &amp; Lubin <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib28\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib28\">2002</a>; Momcheva et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib77\">2006</a>; Auger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib3\">2008</a>; Sluse et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib106\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib106\">2017</a>). However, only small footprints on the sky around a few galaxy-scale lens systems have been observed with deep follow-up spectroscopy. So, how common these structures are is not well constrained. If gravitational lensing is going to be one of the several methods used to determine <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to &lt;1% accuracy, which is also needed for upcoming dark energy studies (e.g., Linder <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib65\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib65\">2011</a>), systematics such as those due to local environment and LOS mass must be quantified.</p><p>We use a spectroscopically-sampled subset of 26 of 28 galaxy-scale strong gravitational lenses (Momcheva et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib78\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib78\">2015</a>; Wilson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>) to constrain the lens environments and LOS structures. We use the convergences and shears to assess the importance of groups. The uncertainty due to lens environment and LOS structures is a systematic, rather than statistical, uncertainty. Convergence, which affects the measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, is not measured on the sky like shear, nor can it be inferred through models. So, it is important to constrain uncertainties due to groups specifically.</p><p>In our analyses, we consider convergences or shears of individual groups or total LOSs to be significant if they are \u22650.01. We adopt this threshold because a convergence of 0.01 will correspond to a 1% bias in <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> (as <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn6.gif\" alt=\"$h\\propto (1-\\kappa )$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">h\\propto (1-\\kappa )</script></span></span>; Keeton &amp; Zabludoff <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib52\">2004</a>), the level of precision necessary for this method to independently constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> at the current leading levels of precision using other methods (see, e.g., Keeton &amp; Zabludoff <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib52\">2004</a>). Shears of 0.01 lead to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn7.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 3\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 3\\sigma</script></span></span> effects, because shear enters the lens equation as <em>\u03b3</em> multiplied by the lensed image position, which usually has uncertainties <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn8.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 003$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 003</script></span></span> (Courbin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib22\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib22\">1997</a>). The uncertainty due to time delay measurements (e.g., Suyu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib110\">2013</a>) and constraints on the external convergence derived statistically from galaxy counts and cosmological simulations (e.g., Rusu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib102\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib102\">2017</a>) have been at the ~1%\u20132% level. In addition, we consider convergences and shears \u22650.05. The 5% level is about the level of discrepancy persisting between different methods of measuring <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>.</p><p>We describe the data in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s2\">2</a> and our lensing formalism in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s3\">3</a>. We then discuss the importance of groups to lensing in the order in which complexity historically has been added to lensing models when considering convergence, which is not measured on the sky: we first examine the lens environment (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s5\">5</a>) then LOS structures (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s6\">6</a>). We structure our discussion of shear in the same way for clarity; however, we note that total shear is measured on the sky, and historically increasing complexity has involved dividing that shear into a larger number of possible contributors (i.e., lens environment and LOS groups) rather than adding extra terms. Additionally, we look for differences in environment and LOS structures for systems with quad and double image morphologies (Sections <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s5-3\">5.3</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s6-3\">6.3</a>, respectively). We consider implications of the convergences due to groups for measuring <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s7\">7</a>. Finally, in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s8\">8</a>, we investigate the relationship between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>.</p><p>Throughout this paper, we adopt the values of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a071 km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}=0.274$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}=0.274</script></span></span>, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.726$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.726</script></span></span> (Hinshaw et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib38\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib38\">2009</a>).</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653s2\" name=\"apjaa9653s2\">2.\u00a0The Data</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s2-1\" name=\"apjaa9653s2-1\">2.1.\u00a0Sample Selection</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The lens sample selection is described in Momcheva et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib78\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib78\">2015</a>). It depended in part on the ancillary data available at the time of spectroscopic observations as well as the lens fields' accessibility from the telescope site. Some early preference was given to fields with known large shears, ill-fitting models, and/or poorly characterized lens environments.</p><p>Williams et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib127\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib127\">2006</a>) detailed the collection and reduction of the photometry in the 28 lens fields. Galaxy redshifts were obtained by Momcheva et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib78\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib78\">2015</a>) for a subset of the photometric objects in those fields; the spectroscopically well-sampled regions have radii ranging from <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 5^{\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 5^{\\prime}</script></span></span> to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 20^{\\prime} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 20^{\\prime}</script></span></span> from the lens. These large sampled regions allow for the identification and accurate determination of group properties (i.e., group centroid and group velocity dispersion), which can significantly impact the lensing potential even when the group is projected a few arcminutes from the lens.</p><p>For 26 of the 28 fields with the most complete spectroscopic data, Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>) created a group catalog including any groups projected along the sightline to the lens as well as groups in which the lens galaxy is itself a member. The properties of these 26 fields are listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t1\">1</a>, and the lens system references are given in Appendix <xref summary=\"e given in Appendix A. Here we use Wilson\">A</xref>. Here we use Wilson et al.'s group velocity dispersions, mean redshifts, and projected spatial centroids. We focus primarily on the subset of 21 fields with lenses with firm spectroscopic redshifts. We consider one additional lens field, b0712, which has both a group at the lens and a large foreground supergroup (Wilson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>), when analyzing lens environments (Sections <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s5\">5</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s7\">7</a>; Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f8\">8</a>), but exclude it elsewhere due to the uncertain mass of the supergroup (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s3\">3</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjaa9653t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nLens Systems\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" alt=\"${N}_{\\mathrm{grp}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{\\mathrm{grp}}</script></span></span>\n<sup>d</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{grp}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{grp}}</script></span></span>\n<sup>d</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">R<sup>d</sup><sup>,</sup><sup>e</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"right\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}</script></span></span>\n<sup>d</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" char=\".\">0.80</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fna\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>From CASTLES (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/castles/\">https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/castles/</a>): Number = Number of images, R = Einstein ring, and E = Extended.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fnb\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>Estimates of twice the average Einstein radius from CASTLES.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fnc\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>From CASTLES: 0\u00a0=\u00a0Literature estimate, 1\u00a0=\u00a0Maximum image pair separation, 2\u00a0=\u00a0Twice average distance from lens center to images, 3\u00a0=\u00a0Twice an SIS model's critical radius plus external shear.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fnd\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fnd\"></a><sup> d</sup>Lens group properties from Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>).\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fne\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fne\"></a><sup> e</sup>Projected angular distance between the lens and the group centroid.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fnf\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fnf\"></a><sup> f</sup>Photometric redshift from Kneib et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib55\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib55\">1998</a>).\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fng\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fng\"></a><sup> g</sup>From CASTLES.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fnh\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fnh\"></a><sup> h</sup>Photometric redshift from CASTLES.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fni\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fni\"></a><sup> i</sup>Photometric redshift from Kochanek et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib57\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib57\">2000</a>).\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fnj\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fnj\"></a><sup> j</sup>Spectroscopic redshift from Chavushyan et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib14\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib14\">1997</a>).\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t1fnk\" id=\"apjaa9653t1fnk\"></a><sup> k</sup>Spectroscopic redshift from Auger et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib3\">2008</a>).\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa9653\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s2-2\" name=\"apjaa9653s2-2\">2.2.\u00a0Photometry</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The Mosaic-1 imager on the Kitt Peak National Observatory Mayall 4 m telescope and the Mosaic II imager on the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory Blanco 4 m telescope were used to collect images through the \"nearly Mould\" <em>I</em>-band filter and either the Harris <em>V</em> filter or the Harris <em>R</em> filter (depending on the redshift of the lens galaxy). SExtractor version 2.3.2's MAG_AUTO (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib8\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib8\">1996</a>) was used to determine the Kron (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib59\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib59\">1980</a>) Vega magnitudes in the <em>I</em>-band. Colors were measured by degrading one image to the resolution of the other then calculating the aperture magnitudes. A calibration was applied to put the photometry on the Kron\u2013Cousins filter system. The photometry was not corrected to total magnitudes. The star\u2013galaxy separation limit was 21.5 mag.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s2-3\" name=\"apjaa9653s2-3\">2.3.\u00a0Spectroscopy</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The spectra were obtained using Hectospec on the MMT 6.5 m telescope and LDSS-2, LDSS-3, and IMACS on the Magellan 6.5 m telescopes. A method based on the routine of Cool et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib21\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib21\">2008</a>), which fits measured spectra to templates and selects that with the lowest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn34.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }^{2}</script></span></span>, was used to measure the redshifts. Objects in the photometry that were not followed up but that had redshifts in NED<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjaa9653fn1\">8</a></sup>\n were added to the redshift catalog. The resulting catalog includes 10,002 unique galaxy redshifts, with 79.4% between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.1 and 0.7 and a median redshift of 0.360.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s2-4\" name=\"apjaa9653s2-4\">2.4.\u00a0Group Catalog</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><h4 id=\"apjaa9653s2-4-1\" name=\"apjaa9653s2-4-1\">2.4.1.\u00a0Group Finding Algorithm</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We use all groups in Tables 1, 2, and 4 of Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>) in the lens beams to include all the observed mass. This sample thus includes groups with as few as three member galaxies, for which group properties are difficult to accurately determine, and groups that our algorithm did not find that we added in manually with differently determined group properties. So, the formal uncertainties on the convergence and shear (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s3\">3</a>) consequently are large.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjaa9653t2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 2.</b>\u00a0\nSummary of Lensing Parameters for Each Field\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">wfi2033</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">10</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"right\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" type=\"math/tex\">{0.003}_{-0.002}^{+0.002}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"right\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\"
