type=\"math/tex\">{0.017}_{-0.008}^{+0.007}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"right\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn162.gif\" alt=\"${0.065}_{-0.021}^{+0.053}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.065}_{-0.021}^{+0.053}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"right\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn163.gif\" alt=\"${0.033}_{-0.022}^{+0.034}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.033}_{-0.022}^{+0.034}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"right\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn164.gif\" alt=\"${0.068}_{-0.022}^{+0.053}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.068}_{-0.022}^{+0.053}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"right\">\n<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn165.gif\" alt=\"${0.049}_{-0.024}^{+0.030}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.049}_{-0.024}^{+0.030}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t2fna\" id=\"apjaa9653t2fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Values presented here include the supergroup. See Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s3\">3</a> and Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t3\">3</a> for details.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t2_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa9653\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t2_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>To check whether this inclusiveness is biasing our results, we repeat our analysis discarding manually-added groups and others with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn166.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{m}\\lt 5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{m}\\lt 5</script></span></span> (as groups with fewer members are more likely to be spurious), <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn167.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}\\leqslant 200$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}\\leqslant 200</script></span></span> km s<sup>\u22121</sup> (such structures might be cuts through galaxy filaments or sheets misidentified as bound groups), <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn168.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{grp}}\\lt 0.1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{grp}}\\lt 0.1</script></span></span> (where only our smallest groups are sampled out to at least <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn169.gif\" alt=\"$1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}</script></span></span> given our typical field sizes, resulting in possibly ill-determined group properties), or are near the field edge (as the group centroid could be biased). With this clean sample, we get qualitatively similar results.</p><p>All of our groups are at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn170.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{grp}}\\lt {z}_{{\\rm{S}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{grp}}\\lt {z}_{{\\rm{S}}}</script></span></span>, where <em>z</em><sub>S</sub> is the redshift of the source, so any might contribute to the lensing of the source. In most fields, our group catalog is more sensitive at redshifts below the lens redshift (<em>z</em><sub>L</sub>) than between <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> and <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>. McCully et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib73\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib73\">2017</a>) find that structures in front of the lens are more likely to significantly affect the lensing potential than those between the lens and the source. Thus, any groups we miss at the redshifts above that of the lenses are less likely to be significant.</p></div><h4 id=\"apjaa9653s2-4-2\" name=\"apjaa9653s2-4-2\">2.4.2.\u00a0Lens Groups</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Having characterized the groups in these 26 fields, we now see whether any of the lens galaxies are also group members, since mass at the redshift of the lens can significantly affect the lensing potential. Our group finder does not treat lens galaxies differently, so nothing about the algorithm should be preferentially selecting structures at the lens' redshifts. However, the fields, and thus our spectroscopic coverage, were centered on the lenses, so if there are structures they are more likely to be found than if they were at the same redshifts elsewhere in the fields. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t1\">1</a> lists the lens and lens group properties, where present, for the 26 lenses in the 26 fields in our group catalog. As stated in Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>), 13 of our lenses are assigned to groups.</p><p>The distributions of lens group velocity dispersions and redshifts are given in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f1\">1</a>. The velocity dispersions range from ~100\u2013800 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> (although some have large uncertainties). Most lens groups have slightly higher velocity dispersions than the average for our overall group sample. The effect may arise from the lower spectroscopic completeness away from the lens (Momcheva et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib78\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib78\">2015</a>), as group velocity dispersion tends to be underestimated when its members' redshift distribution is undersampled (Zabludoff &amp; Mulchaey <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib134\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib134\">1998</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Redshifts and velocity dispersions for our group sample (gray) with lens groups highlighted (black). Black crosses at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn171.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}=0$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}=0</script></span></span> mark the redshifts of lenses that are not identified as group galaxies; most are at higher redshifts where our group catalog is less sensitive. Four lenses do not have firm spectroscopic redshifts and thus could not have been assigned group membership. Out of 26 lenses, at least 13 are in groups. The velocity dispersion distributions of lens and non-lens groups are statistically distinguishable using a Mann\u2013Whitney\u2013Wilcoxon test, but this difference is likely caused by a difference in variance rather than mean.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>To ascertain whether the velocity dispersions of lens groups are in fact different, we compare our lens groups only to LOS groups with projected spatial centroids within <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn172.gif\" alt=\"${5}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{5}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> of the lenses (typically the best sampled region in all our fields). A Mann\u2013Whitney\u2013Wilcoxon (MWW) test (Wilcoxon <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib126\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib126\">1945</a>; Mann &amp; Whitney <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib69\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib69\">1947</a>) distinguishes between the two distributions at &gt;95% confidence, a result likely to be dominated by the distributions' different variances. To check for differences between the means of the two velocity dispersion distributions, we perform a \"bootstrap means comparison\" (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653app2\">B</a>), drawing from the 13 best-sampled non-lens groups and finding that their mean velocity dispersion is at least as large as that of the lens groups in 6.9% of 1000 trials.</p><p>The falling sensitivity of our redshift catalog (Momcheva et al. 2015) results in few groups above <em>z</em>\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a00.6. Four of nine of the lenses with <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.6 either have only a photometric redshift or an uncertain spectroscopic redshift, so we do not assign them group membership. For example, Auger et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib3\">2008</a>) identify sbs1520 as lying in a group, but we do not do so here because there are several different lens redshift estimates in the literature.</p><p>Of the other five lenses that have good spectroscopic lens redshifts, only one is classified here as a group member. Another has a redshift nearby those of two groups, and a third lies in an apparent redshift overdensity. MG1131 and q0158 (which is at lower redshift), have tentative group identifications based on photometry.</p><p>In summary, 12 of 17 (71%) lenses at <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.6 are in groups. At <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a00.6, only one of five (20%) lenses with firm spectroscopic redshifts is a group member, suggesting significant incompleteness at high <em>z</em>. Our lenses reside in group environments at least half the time, and these groups have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn173.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}</script></span></span> comparable to others along the sightlines. We now investigate the lensing properties of these groups in more depth.</p></div></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653s3\" name=\"apjaa9653s3\">3.\u00a0Lensing Formalism</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>First, we summarize how convergence and shear enter into the calculation of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from time-delay measurements (e.g., Suyu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib110\">2013</a>; for a review of time delay cosmography, see Treu &amp; Marshall <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib116\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib116\">2016</a>).</p><p>The extra time it takes light from the source to reach the observer compared to if there were no lensing is</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&t({\\boldsymbol{\\theta }},{\\boldsymbol{\\beta }})=\\displaystyle \\frac{{D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}}{c}\\left[\\displaystyle \\frac{{({\\boldsymbol{\\theta }}-{\\boldsymbol{\\beta }})}^{2}}{2}-\\psi ({\\boldsymbol{\\theta }})\\right],\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where image angular position <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn174.gif\" alt=\"${\\boldsymbol{\\theta }}=({\\theta }_{1},{\\theta }_{2})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\boldsymbol{\\theta }}=({\\theta }_{1},{\\theta }_{2})</script></span></span>, source position <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn175.gif\" alt=\"${\\boldsymbol{\\beta }}=({\\beta }_{1},{\\beta }_{2})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\boldsymbol{\\beta }}=({\\beta }_{1},{\\beta }_{2})</script></span></span>, <em>c</em> is the speed of light, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn176.gif\" alt=\"$\\psi ({\\boldsymbol{\\theta }})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\psi ({\\boldsymbol{\\theta }})</script></span></span> is the lens potential. <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn177.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}</script></span></span> is the time-delay distance,</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn2.gif\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}\\equiv (1+{z}_{{\\rm{L}}})\\displaystyle \\frac{{D}_{{\\rm{L}}}{D}_{{\\rm{S}}}}{{D}_{{\\rm{LS}}}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> is the lens redshift and <em>D</em><sub>L</sub>, <em>D</em><sub>S</sub>, and <em>D</em><sub>LS</sub> are angular diameter distances between, respectively, the observer and the lens, the observer and the source, and the source and the lens. The time-delay distance is inversely proportional to <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, as well as weakly dependent on other cosmological parameters.</p><p>Because of the mass sheet degeneracy, lensing data alone cannot constrain external convergence. Therefore it is common to fit models that omit convergence, which yield an estimate for the time delay distance of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn178.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}^{\\mathrm{model}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}^{\\mathrm{model}}</script></span></span>. When external convergence is applied, the new estimate for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn179.gif\" alt=\"${D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}</script></span></span> is</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn3.gif\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{D}_{{\\rm{\\Delta }}t}^{\\mathrm{model}}}{1-\\kappa }.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p>Convergences thus enter the calculation as 1 \u2212 <em>\u03ba</em> from the mass sheet degeneracy, and shear appears inside the model-dependent factor.</p><p>We calculate the effective convergence (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn180.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>) and shear (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn181.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>) for each group, as well as total convergence (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn182.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>) and shear (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn183.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>) for each field, using the following method.</p><p>Here we focus on determining the importance of <em>groups</em> to the lensing potential. We do not model the lens galaxy. We also do not consider any galaxies that have not been assigned to groups, leaving that to more detailed future modeling (e.g., Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib132\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib132\">2011</a>; McCully et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib73\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib73\">2017</a>).</p><p>We assume that each group's mass is described by a group halo and that there is no appreciable mass bound to the individual group galaxies (the group halo limit). Using preliminary redshift catalogs for eight of these systems, Momcheva et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib77\">2006</a>) find that assigning the mass to the group halo or to individual member galaxy halos does not affect which groups are significant to the lensing potential.</p><p>Using weak lensing measurements of galaxy groups with masses <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn184.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim {10}^{13}\\mbox{--}{10}^{14.5}\\,{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim {10}^{13}\\mbox{--}{10}^{14.5}\\,{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>, Viola et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib121\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib121\">2015</a>) find that the density profiles agree with that expected for Navarro, Frenk, and White (NFW) profiles (Navarro et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib87\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib87\">1996</a>). So, we model the groups in each lens field as NFW halos, estimating the scale radius <em>r</em><sub>s</sub> and central density <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn185.gif\" alt=\"${\\rho }_{{\\rm{s}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\rho }_{{\\rm{s}}}</script></span></span> of a halo from its redshift and velocity dispersion using the results of simulations by Zhao et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib135\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib135\">2009</a>). We assume the groups generally are virialized, as many have centrally concentrated early-type populations. For any non-virialized systems, the masses derived from the velocity dispersions here could be overestimated by up to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn186.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 2\\times $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 2\\times</script></span></span>, if the measured dispersion is closer to the infall velocity. This systematic would bias the lensing contribution upward.</p><p>We then calculate the convergence (<em>\u03ba</em>) and shear (<em>\u03b3</em>) for each halo using the truncated NFW profile formalism given in Baltz et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib6\">2009</a>) to calculate the projected surface mass density (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn187.gif\" alt=\"${\\rm{\\Sigma }}(x)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\rm{\\Sigma }}(x)</script></span></span>) and the mean projected surface density (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn188.gif\" alt=\"$\\bar{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\bar{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}</script></span></span>). For these, we use <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn189.gif\" alt=\"$x=r/{r}_{{\\rm{s}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">x=r/{r}_{{\\rm{s}}}</script></span></span>, where <em>r</em> is the distance between the group center and the lens LOS at the redshift of the group, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn190.gif\" alt=\"$\\tau =\\tfrac{{r}_{{\\rm{t}}}}{{r}_{{\\rm{s}}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\tau =\\tfrac{{r}_{{\\rm{t}}}}{{r}_{{\\rm{s}}}}</script></span></span>, where <em>r</em><sub>t</sub> is the truncation radius. We choose <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn191.gif\" alt=\"${r}_{200{\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{200{\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span> as our truncation radius (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653app3\">C</a> for a discussion). We calculate</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn4\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn4.gif\" alt=\"Equation (4)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{s}}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{r}_{{\\rm{s}}}{\\rho }_{{\\rm{s}}}}{{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{\\mathrm{crit}}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t4\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>and</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn5\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn5.gif\" alt=\"Equation (5)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{\\mathrm{crit}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{c}^{2}}{4\\pi G}\\displaystyle \\frac{{D}_{{\\rm{S}}}}{{D}_{{\\rm{P}}}{D}_{{\\rm{PS}}}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t5\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>D</em><sub>S</sub>, <em>D</em><sub>P</sub>, and <em>D</em><sub>PS</sub> are the angular diameter distances between the observer and the source, the observer and the perturbing group, and the perturbing group and the source, respectively. Next, we calculate the convergence</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn6\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn6.gif\" alt=\"Equation (6)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\kappa =\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}{{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{\\mathrm{crit}}}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t6\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>and the shear</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn7\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn7.gif\" alt=\"Equation (7)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\gamma =\\displaystyle \\frac{\\bar{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}-{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}{{{\\rm{\\Sigma }}}_{\\mathrm{crit}}}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t7\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>in the perturber's plane.</p><p>Now, as in Momcheva et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib77\">2006</a>), we define</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn8\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn8.gif\" alt=\"Equation (8)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\beta =\\displaystyle \\frac{D({z}_{1},{z}_{2})D(0,{z}_{{\\rm{S}}})}{D(0,{z}_{2})D({z}_{1},{z}_{{\\rm{S}}})},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t8\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn9\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn9.gif\" alt=\"Equation (9)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{z}_{1}=\\min ({z}_{{\\rm{L}}},{z}_{{\\rm{P}}}),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t9\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>and</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn10\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn10.gif\" alt=\"Equation (10)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{z}_{2}=\\max ({z}_{{\\rm{L}}},{z}_{{\\rm{P}}}).\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t10\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p>When the convergence and shear is due to a perturber, the expressions for its effective convergence and shear more generally are</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn11\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn11.gif\" alt=\"Equation (11)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{(1-\\beta )[\\kappa -\\beta ({\\kappa }^{2}-{\\gamma }^{2})]}{{(1-\\beta \\kappa )}^{2}-{(\\beta \\gamma )}^{2}}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t11\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>and</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn12\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn12.gif\" alt=\"Equation (12)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{(1-\\beta )\\gamma }{{(1-\\beta \\kappa )}^{2}-{(\\beta \\gamma )}^{2}},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t12\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>as given in Keeton (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib48\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib48\">2003</a>). In this analysis, all groups are treated the same, regardless of whether the lens galaxy is a member. For the groups that do have lens galaxies as members, <em>\u03b2</em> is small, approaching zero for a lens that is near the velocity centroid of its group, so <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn192.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn193.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> will approach <em>\u03ba</em> and <em>\u03b3</em>.</p><p>We estimate the total effective convergence due to all the groups in the field for each lens LOS using</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn13\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn13.gif\" alt=\"Equation (13)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}=\\displaystyle \\sum _{{i}}{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},{i}}\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t13\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>from Momcheva et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib77\">2006</a>). We calculate the effective convergence due to each group halo, including the lens group halo, and sum them in each field to estimate the importance of LOS structures and lens environment for the lensing potential.</p><p>Since the shears add as tensors, we measure <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn194.gif\" alt=\"${\\theta }_{\\gamma }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\theta }_{\\gamma }</script></span></span>, the position angle measured north through east between the group projected spatial centroid and the lens. This definition is consistent with the direction in which the lensing critical curve is stretched but is orthogonal to the direction in which an image would be stretched.</p><p>We then calculate the total shear components for each field as</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn14\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn14.gif\" alt=\"Equation (14)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{c}},{\\rm{tot}}}=\\displaystyle \\sum _{i}{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\cos 2{\\theta }_{\\gamma ,i},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t14\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn15\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn15.gif\" alt=\"Equation (15)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{s}},{\\rm{tot}}}=\\displaystyle \\sum _{i}{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\sin 2{\\theta }_{\\gamma ,i},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t15\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>and</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn16\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn16.gif\" alt=\"Equation (16)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}=\\sqrt{{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{c}},\\mathrm{tot}}^{2}+{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{s}},\\mathrm{tot}}^{2}}.\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t16\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>The total position angle of the shear is</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaa9653eqn17\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653eqn17.gif\" alt=\"Equation (17)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{\\theta }_{\\gamma ,\\mathrm{tot}}=\\displaystyle \\frac{1}{2}\\arctan \\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{s}},\\mathrm{tot}}}{{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{c}},\\mathrm{tot}}}\\right).\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t17\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n</p><p>These calculations for the total values assume that there are no lensing interactions between the halos which arise from cross-terms in the multi-plane lens equation, which is a simplification (see McCully et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib72\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib72\">2014</a>).</p><p>We may underestimate the velocity dispersions of groups at <em>z</em>\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a00.6, because a lower fraction of true members may have been observed due to our lower sensitivity. This underestimate would result in an underestimation of their effect on the lensing. Thus, the true properties would result in stronger effects, making our results conservative.</p><p>Plots showing the distribution of the angular and redshift separation of groups from the lens color coded by their <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn195.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> are given in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f2\">2</a>. Sky plots of the fields with groups marked and their <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn196.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> values indicated are given in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f3\">3</a>. Groups contribute to the total convergence in several ways. Some fields have one dominant group, some have multiple important ones, and one has several unimportant groups that add up to a significant contribution. In the cases where there is one dominant group, this is not always the lens group. As shears can add or subtract depending on relative position angles, fields with multiple important groups can have larger or smaller <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn197.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f2a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f2a_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f2a\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f2a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f2a\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f2a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f2b_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f2b\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f2b\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f2b\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f2b\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f2c_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Redshift, angular separation from the lens, and convergence values of groups (open circles) in our 25 fields with lens and source redshift measurements. Circle sizes are scaled by group velocity dispersion. Points are color coded by <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn198.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>. Groups that include the lens galaxies are marked additionally with black crosses. The supergroup in field b0712 is included. Gray dashed lines mark spectroscopic lens redshifts, and gray dotted lines mark photometric redshifts. The lens of sbs1520 has two possible values, so we use <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.72 in the calculations but mark where the other value would be with a second dashed gray line. Groups behind the lens are above the gray lines, and those in the foreground are below. Red or orange circles indicate significant groups, usually because they are near the lens in redshift and/or on the sky (small <em>R</em>) and/or are massive (large circles). Groups marked in blue or green are not important, usually because they are far from the lens and/or are low mass. There is a diversity in how groups contribute to their fields' lensing potentials. Some have one clearly dominant group, some have multiple important groups, and one has many individually insignificant groups that add up to an overall significant <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn199.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f2c\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f2c\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f2c\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f2c\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f3a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f3a_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f3a\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f3a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f3a\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f3a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f3b_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f3b\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f3b\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f3b\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f3b\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f3c_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Distribution of groups on the sky relative to the lens for our 25 fields with lens and source redshifts. Black points mark groups, green crosses mark lens groups, cyan crosses mark the LOS groups with the largest <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn200.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>, and the green filled circles mark lens galaxies. The supergroup in field b0712 is included. Black lines are scaled by the group's <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn201.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and point away from the lens to depict the group's position angle, although the shear is invariant under a 180\u00b0 rotation. Groups without lines have shears too small for the line to be visible (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn202.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\lesssim 0.003$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\lesssim 0.003</script></span></span>). The field's <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn203.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> is represented by the pink line, and the field's <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn204.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span>, the total shear without the lens galaxy, by the purple line for fields with lens groups. These values also are invariant under a 180\u00b0 rotation and are scaled so the full length is equal to the line length of a group with equal <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn205.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>. Since we define the position angle to point in the direction of the perturber, the critical curves would be elongated in the directions represented by these lines, and images would be stretched orthogonally. The typical uncertainties in <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn206.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn207.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> are, respectively, 0.003 and 0.02. Although we represent the group shears as a vector field they add as tensors. For some fields, the direction and magnitude of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn208.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> is driven by one group. This is not always the lens group. Several fields have several significant groups; their shears can add or subtract depending on their relative position angles.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f3c\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f3c\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f3c\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f3c\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f4\">4</a> shows the histograms of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn209.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn210.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> for fields with and without lens groups. A Kolmogorov\u2013Smirnov (K-S) test comparing the unbinned distributions is significant at 95% confidence, suggesting that there is a tail to higher <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn211.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn212.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> in fields where the lens lies in a group. Furthermore, our bootstrap means comparison (Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653app2\">B</a>) indicates a &lt;0.1% chance that the mean <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn213.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn214.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> for fields with lenses in groups are as small as the values for fields with lenses not in groups. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t2\">2</a> summarizes the lensing parameters for each field, and Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t3\">3</a> lists the individual group properties and lensing parameters in each field.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Distribution of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn215.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> (left) and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn216.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> (right) for fields with lenses in groups (white histograms) and those with lenses that have not been identified as group members (filled gray) for the 21 fields with firm spectroscopic lens redshifts and without a supergroup. These total values include the lens group contributions. Bin widths are different for <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn217.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn218.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> because of their different average uncertainties. Fields with lens groups have a tail extending to large <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn219.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}</script></span></span> that is not present in fields without lens groups.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f4\"
