type=\"math/tex\">{0.107}_{-0.026}^{+0.051}</script></span></span>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">89</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong> Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t3\">3</a> is published in its entirety in the electronic edition of the <em>Astrophysical Journal</em>. A portion is shown here for guidance regarding its form and content.</p>\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t3fna\" id=\"apjaa9653t3fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Lens group.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t3fnb\" id=\"apjaa9653t3fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>Numbering as in Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>).\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t3fnc\" id=\"apjaa9653t3fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>From Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>). Uncertainties in group properties other than number of member galaxies are provided for groups with at least four members.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t3fnd\" id=\"apjaa9653t3fnd\"></a><sup> d</sup>Projected distance between the group projected spatial centroid and the lens from Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>).\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t3fne\" id=\"apjaa9653t3fne\"></a><sup> e</sup>Angle measured north through east between the group projected spatial centroid and the lens.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t3fnf\" id=\"apjaa9653t3fnf\"></a><sup> f</sup>Supergroup.\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t3fng\" id=\"apjaa9653t3fng\"></a><sup> g</sup>Main substructures of the supergroup.\n\n\n\n<p>Only a portion of this table is shown here to demonstrate its form and content. A <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t3_mrt.txt\">machine-readable</a> version of the full table is available.</p>\n\n\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-table-data\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t3_mrt.txt\" target=\"_blank\">Data</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t3_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>All statistical tests are performed on unbinned data; we bin only to visually present the data.</p><p>In these plots and tables, we include all 25 fields with spectroscopic or photometric lens and source redshift estimates. Field h12531 is discarded because it lacks a source redshift estimate. The fields surrounding four lenses without firm spectroscopic redshifts (h1413, h12531, q1017, and sbs1520) could not have lens groups identified, so for the rest of the analysis we discard them.</p><p>In field b0712, our group finding algorithm identifies a supergroup (a structure with multiple well-populated clumps in both velocity and projected on the sky; Wilson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>). We separately calculate the convergence and shear of the supergroup as a whole and for its three main substructures, as listed in Table 3 of Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>). If the supergroup is treated as one monolithic halo, it is very significant (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn272.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}=$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}=</script></span></span> <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn273.gif\" alt=\"${0.308}_{-0.115}^{+0.229}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.308}_{-0.115}^{+0.229}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn274.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}={0.180}_{-0.042}^{+0.072}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}={0.180}_{-0.042}^{+0.072}</script></span></span>). If the mass distribution is better described by treating the substructures separately, none has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn275.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> or <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn276.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>. Accurately determining how big an effect this supergroup has on the lensing potential requires further observations and analysis. We thus include this field in our field overview plots (Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f2\">2</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f3\">3</a>) and in our discussion of lens group environments (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s5\">5</a>), but we discard it elsewhere because of these uncertainties.</p><p>We calculate uncertainties in our effective convergences and shears due to the uncertainty in the measured group properties using the bootstrap method. We resample with replacement the identified group members and recalculate <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn277.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{grp}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{grp}}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn278.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{grp}}</script></span></span>, and the group projected spatial centroid for 1000 iterations. Using those recalculated group properties, we then calculate the resulting <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn279.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn280.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>. We then calculate and subtract the median <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn281.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn282.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> values over all 1000 iterations and determine the 16th and 84th percentiles for individual groups as well as for <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn283.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn284.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>.</p><p>The median values can differ from the measured values. Since we resample the observed group members with replacement, a bootstrap realization's velocity dispersion is more likely to be smaller than measured, leading to smaller convergences and shears. The fractional differences in the measured and median values (i.e., <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn285.gif\" alt=\"$({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{obs}}-{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{med}})/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{obs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{obs}}-{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{med}})/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{obs}}</script></span></span>) show no strong trend with increasing lensing parameter value. Also, the mean fractional errors in the lensing parameters are almost twice as large as the mean fractional differences due to the bootstrap realizations (a fractional difference of the median from the observed convergence of 0.37 versus a fractional differences of the error in convergence from the observed convergence of 0.60, and 0.28 versus 0.50 for corresponding quantities for shear).</p><p>We do not incorporate uncertainty in the NFW concentration parameter associated with scatter in the mass/concentration relation. Wong et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib132\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib132\">2011</a>) find that such uncertainties affect shears on the order of <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" />0.01, generally when the group centroid is very close to the lens. In that case, other uncertainties, such as in the total mass, still dominate.</p><p>Prior work has been done on a subset of these fields using an earlier version of the redshift catalog and a different group catalog (e.g., Momcheva et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib77\">2006</a>; Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib132\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib132\">2011</a>). The formalism we use here is different than used previously; for group halos, we use truncated NFW profiles whereas Momcheva et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib77\">2006</a>) use isothermal spheres and Wong et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib132\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib132\">2011</a>) use untruncated NFW profiles. Wong et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib132\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib132\">2011</a>), Ammons et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib2\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib2\">2014</a>) and McCully et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib73\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib73\">2017</a>) fully model the lens mass distributions (i.e., with GRAVLENS; Keeton <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib47\">2001</a>) in several of these fields.</p><p>To see how our simple treatment compares, in one field (fbq0951) we calculate <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn286.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn287.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> for the groups with at least five galaxies and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn288.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{\\mathrm{vir}}\\gt {10}^{13}{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\mathrm{vir}}\\gt {10}^{13}{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> using the methodology of Ammons et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib2\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib2\">2014</a>). For <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn289.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn290.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\gt 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\gt 0.01</script></span></span>, generally for systems projected closer to the lens and/or with large velocity dispersions, our values agree within the large uncertainties caused by group property uncertainties. For smaller values of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn291.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn292.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> our values are generally slightly smaller. This difference can be attributed to our using truncated NFW profiles, which result in smaller halo masses and projected surface mass densities when the halo is projected farther than the truncation radius from the lens sightline rather than the untruncated NFW halos that Ammons et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib2\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib2\">2014</a>) use. Our <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn293.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> value is also slightly lower. This difference is partly due to our assuming a different mass profile. However, it is also partly because we assume that the halos affect the lensing potential independently; we would expect the results from the full treatment, which includes nonlinear effects of interactions between LOS halos (McCully et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib72\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib72\">2014</a>), to be different. Overall, though, the agreement is reasonable; we calculate, using the subset of groups for this field, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn294.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}={0.23}_{-0.06}^{+0.10}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}={0.23}_{-0.06}^{+0.10}</script></span></span> and 0.29 and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn295.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}={0.04}_{-0.03}^{+0.04}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}={0.04}_{-0.03}^{+0.04}</script></span></span> and 0.04 for our formalism and that of Ammons et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib2\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib2\">2014</a>), respectively.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653s4\" name=\"apjaa9653s4\">4.\u00a0Comparison with the Literature</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Several of our systems have been previously identified as needing external shears to explain the image morphology and produce adequately-fitting models. We compare our calculated shears for these systems (b1422, mg1654, pg1115, and rxj1131) with the values reported by, respectively, Chiba (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib16\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib16\">2002</a>) and Nierenberg et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib89\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib89\">2014</a>) (both for b1422), Wallington et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib122\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib122\">1996</a>), Chiba (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib16\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib16\">2002</a>), and Claeskens et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib17\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib17\">2006</a>) and Suyu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib110\">2013</a>) (both for rxj1131). Our <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn296.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> values agree with those in the literature within their 3<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties except for field rxj1131.</p><p>Claeskens et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib17\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib17\">2006</a>) find that their best-fitting models of rxj1131 include external shear. Their best model (using a singular isothermal ellipsoid plus an octupole for the lens and external shear) has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn297.gif\" alt=\"$\\gamma =0.124$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gamma =0.124</script></span></span>, much larger than what we calculate (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn298.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}={0.019}_{-0.010}^{+0.012}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}={0.019}_{-0.010}^{+0.012}</script></span></span>). Suyu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib110\">2013</a>) model an external shear of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn299.gif\" alt=\"${0.089}_{-0.006}^{+0.006}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.089}_{-0.006}^{+0.006}</script></span></span>, which is also larger than we measure. However, they find a probability distribution function for the external convergence that peaks around 0.08, in qualitative agreement with our <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn300.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}={0.061}_{-0.016}^{+0.024}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}={0.061}_{-0.016}^{+0.024}</script></span></span>.</p><p>The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn301.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0.1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0.1</script></span></span> cluster and the lens group both have possible X-ray detections in the literature (2\u20133<b>&#x00d7;</b>10<sup>43</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, Morgan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib84\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib84\">2006</a>). The velocity dispersions we measure are consistent with the observed X-ray luminosity\u2013velocity dispersion relation, which has significant scatter, or larger than what would be predicted given the relation of Ortiz-Gil et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib95\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib95\">2004</a>). So we are unlikely to be underestimating the lensing contributions due to these two groups.</p><p>We only consider lensing due to groups. Thus, we are not sensitive to additional shear caused by substructures within the lens. This insensitivity might be why our <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn302.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> for rxj1131 is significantly lower than that modeled by Claeskens et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib17\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib17\">2006</a>) and Suyu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib110\">2013</a>). The latter downplay the possibility of substructure contributing to their modeled shear based on a modeled external convergence gradient and shear position angle. However, Keeton &amp; Moustakas (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib51\">2009</a>) suggest the presence of substructure because of the order of image arrival time observed in time-delay measurements. Cyr-Racine et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib23\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib23\">2016</a>) show, by modeling dark matter subhalos in lenses, that substructures could have an effect, but it is unlikely to be at the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn303.gif\" alt=\"$\\gamma \\sim 0.1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\gamma \\sim 0.1</script></span></span> level. Others have suggested the possibility of lens substructure for b1422 and pg1115 (respectively, Brada\u010d et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib11\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib11\">2002</a>; Miranda &amp; Jetzer <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib75\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib75\">2007</a>). The large uncertainties in our values might wash out the disagreement in these cases. Dark matter substructures are not the only possible explanation, however. Baryonic structures, such as disks, which we also do not model, can have similar effects (e.g., Hsueh et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib39\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib39\">2016</a>, 2017; Gilman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib31\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib31\">2017</a>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib40\"></a>).</p><p>In addition, extensive lensing analyses on he0435 are being performed by the H0LiCOW team (Suyu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib111\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib111\">2017</a>). Sluse et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib106\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib106\">2017</a>) conclude, using flexion shifts, that the groups they identify in this field can be approximated with external shear rather than being modeled explicitly. Rusu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib102\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib102\">2017</a>) constrain <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn304.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{ext}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{ext}}}</script></span></span> to be near zero (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn305.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{ext}}}^{{\\rm{med}}}=0.004$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{ext}}}^{{\\rm{med}}}=0.004</script></span></span>), which is also consistent with the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn306.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{ext}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{ext}}}</script></span></span> determined from an independent weak lensing analysis of this field (O. Tihhonova et al. 2017, in preparation).</p><p>Some of this disagreement between their results and ours can be ascribed to differences in group catalogs and lensing methodology. Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>) identify a larger group at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn307.gif\" alt=\"$z\\sim 0.18$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">z\\sim 0.18</script></span></span> than do Sluse et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib106\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib106\">2017</a>). Also, Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>) use an unweighted centroid, which lies fairly close to the lens and leads to a large convergence <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn308.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{lens}}}={0.091}_{-0.031}^{+0.110}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{lens}}}={0.091}_{-0.031}^{+0.110}</script></span></span>. By contrast, Sluse et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib106\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib106\">2017</a>) use a luminosity-weighted centroid, which lies farther from the lens; if we use their centroid, we calculate <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn309.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{lens}}}=0.035$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{lens}}}=0.035</script></span></span>. These values are still larger than the other estimates of convergence, so Sluse et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib106\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib106\">2017</a>) suggest that the group centroid may actually lie even farther from the lens sightline, or that the lens is actually at the center of its group halo. Additional observations of this field might further constrain the group properties and reconcile these differences.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653s5\" name=\"apjaa9653s5\">5.\u00a0Importance of Lens Groups to External Shear and Convergence</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Groups at the lens can have large impacts on the lensing, as they are projected quite close on the sky and are, by definition, very near the lens redshift (presumably any difference being due to peculiar motion). Thus, we consider here the frequency of important lens groups in our sample. These results are shown in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f5\">5</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f6\">6</a>, and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f7\">7</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f5a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f5a_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0,     Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0Portion of each field's <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn310.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> that is contributed by lens groups (green open circles), the LOS group with the largest <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn311.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> (cyan crosses), and all LOS groups (including the LOS group with the largest <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn312.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> but not including the lens group; purple filled circles). Error bars are calculated from the measurement errors on the group properties using the bootstrap method. Fields without lens groups have no lens group value shown. The <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn313.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> (the sum of the lens and all LOS contributions) is marked with a dashed line. Although lens groups sometimes are significant, usually LOS groups are important contributors to <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn314.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f5b\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f5b\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f5b\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f5b\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s5-1\" name=\"apjaa9653s5-1\">5.1.\u00a0Convergence</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>First, we consider <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn315.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and its uncertainty, calculated as described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s3\">3</a>, for only lens groups (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn316.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}</script></span></span>, see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t3\">3</a>). Five of 13 lens groups have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn317.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}</script></span></span> at or above 0.01 and are inconsistent with &lt;0.01 within their 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties. Three of 13 have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn318.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>.</p><p>Next, we consider the fraction of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn319.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> that the lens group contributes (see Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f5\">5</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f6\">6</a>). While some lens groups dominate their fields, most make up a small fraction of the total convergence once LOS groups are considered; only in two fields do the lens groups make up &gt;50% of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn320.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Fraction of each field's <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn321.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> that is contributed by the lens group (top), the LOS group with the largest <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn322.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> (middle), and all LOS groups (including the LOS group with the largest <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn323.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> but not including the lens group, bottom) for fields with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn324.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span> and lens groups. We compare these distributions to test the relative importance of lens groups and the single most important LOS group in fields with both. MWW tests comparing the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn325.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> distribution with, separately, the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn326.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn327.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> distributions are significant. These results suggest that even when lens groups exist they often are not the most important group in the field.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>In summary, several of our fields have significant lens groups, but lens groups rarely are the only important group in the field.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s5-2\" name=\"apjaa9653s5-2\">5.2.\u00a0Shear</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We calculate <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn328.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and its uncertainty for lens groups (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn329.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}</script></span></span>). Eight of 13 lens groups have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn330.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}</script></span></span> above 0.01 and are inconsistent with &lt;0.01 within their 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties. Three of 13 have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn331.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>.</p><p>So, as for convergence, several fields have significant shear from lens groups.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s5-3\" name=\"apjaa9653s5-3\">5.3.\u00a0Lens Environments of Quads versus Doubles</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The measured quad/double ratio is higher than expected (e.g., Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib56\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib56\">1996</a>). Previous studies have suggested that the lens image morphology (i.e., whether there are two or four images) depends on perturbing masses. Keeton &amp; Zabludoff (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib52\">2004</a>) find the quad/double ratio is underestimated when lens galaxy environment is neglected. Momcheva et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib77\">2006</a>) also find a suggestion for a link between lens environment and number of images.</p><p>The high quad/double ratio also might arise from the lens halos being different shapes. For example, Collett &amp; Cunnington (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib19\">2016</a>) find that quad lenses are more elliptical in their synthetic lens sample. Yet the ellipticities needed to produce the observed ratio are larger than typical for elliptical galaxies (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn332.gif\" alt=\"$b/a=0.4$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">b/a=0.4</script></span></span>; Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib56\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib56\">1996</a>). Keeton &amp; Zabludoff (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib52\">2004</a>) show that both a large lens ellipticity (<em>e</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.4) and proper consideration of the lens environment are required to reproduce the observed ratio. Along the same lines, Huterer et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib41\">2005</a>) argue that while increasing lens ellipticity or shear increases the quad/double ratio, an additional contribution is needed, most likely from the lens galaxy environment.</p><p>No direct selection for quads in groups and/or for doubles not in groups was made when the overall lens sample was constructed.</p><p>When we look at double and quad image morphologies here, we do not include any of the systems with ring components. We do include b2114, which has two image pairs, as a double.</p><p>All seven of our quad lenses with firm spectroscopic redshifts are in groups (including b0712, which we discard elsewhere due to the supergroup), but only three of 10 doubles are in groups.</p><p>Using the binomial distribution, we calculate the probability (P-value) of finding at least six of seven quad lenses in groups and no more than three of 10 double lenses in groups, under the hypothesis that the probability of being in a group is the same for both types of lenses. (We discard the b0712 lower confidence lens group here to be conservative; see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s2-4-1\">2.4.1</a>.) The P-value is maximized if the probability of a lens being in a group is 9/17 (which corresponds to the group fraction our combined quad and double sample). That maximal P-value is 1%, so this analysis indicates that the hypothesis that quads and doubles have a universal probability of residing in a group can be ruled out at greater than 95% confidence.</p><p>Groups are easier to find if the spectroscopic completeness is higher, and galaxies in the fields of quad systems were given higher priority during spectroscopic followup. We thus investigate whether this difference in the fraction of lenses in groups is real or an observational bias. For each field, we calculate the fraction of galaxies in our <em>I</em>-band photometry brighter than 20.5 mag, the brighter of the two magnitude limits in our spectroscopic sample, within <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn333.gif\" alt=\"${5}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{5}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> of the lens, the region that was prioritized during spectroscopic followup. We then compare the distributions of spectroscopic completenesses for our quad and double fields. Neither an F- nor a t-test is significant at the \u226595% level. Thus, there is no evidence for the difference in the frequency of quad and double lenses residing in groups in our sample arising from differences in spectroscopic completenesses in their respective fields. One of the high-redshift lenses (bri0952) is located at a redshift between two groups but is not a member. We repeat our calculation only using lenses at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn334.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{lens}}}\\lt 0.6$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{lens}}}\\lt 0.6</script></span></span> and the one lens at higher redshift with no evidence of being a group member. We calculate the probability of finding at least five of six quads lenses in groups and no more than three of eight double lenses in groups if all lenses reside in groups the same fraction of the time to be 4%. This result still indicates that quad and double lenses reside in different environments at better than the 2<em>\u03c3</em> significance level.</p><p>In addition, we perform a Bayesian analysis to compare two models for our systems at all redshifts: in model M1, the probability of being in a group is the same (f) for quads and doubles (as above); in model M2, the probability of being in a group can be different for quads and doubles (fQ and fD, respectively). We write the Bayesian likelihood as the joint probability of finding 6/7 quads and 3/10 doubles in groups, using the binomial distribution for each sample. For M1, integrating over f with uniform priors yields Bayesian evidence EM1\u00a0=\u00a00.0019. For M2, integrating over both fQ and fD with uniform priors yields evidence EM2\u00a0=\u00a00.011. According to the Jeffreys (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib45\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib45\">1961</a>) scale, the Bayes factor EM2/EM1\u00a0=\u00a05.9 provides substantial evidence favoring model M2. A similar conclusion is reached using the scale from Kass &amp; Raftery (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib46\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib46\">1995</a>).</p><p>Therefore, our quad lens galaxies with firm spectroscopic lens redshifts are more likely to be members of groups than those of doubles; lens environment is correlated with image morphology in our sample. This result supports the hypothesis that lens environment is important for explaining the larger than expected quad/double ratio.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653s6\" name=\"apjaa9653s6\">6.\u00a0Importance of Lens LOS Structures to External Shear and Convergence</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Any mass along the LOS will bend light from a background source, so we consider the possible contribution to the lensing potential of groups along our lens LOSs. These results also are shown in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f5\">5</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f6\">6</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f7\">7</a>, and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f8\">8</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f7\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f7\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f7_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 7.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 7.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f7_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 7.</strong>\u00a0Fraction of fields with significant <em>\u03ba </em>(top) or <em>\u03b3 </em>(bottom) for the lens group (out of 13 fields, left column), for the LOS group with the largest contribution (out of 21 fields, middle), and for the total LOS excluding the lens group if present (out of 21 fields, right).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f7\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f7\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f8_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f8_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Distributions of <em>\u03ba</em> (left) and <em>\u03b3</em> (right) for fields with quads (white histograms) vs. those with doubles (solid gray). Top: <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn335.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn336.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> for lens groups only. The b0712 lens group is included in this row, but not in the LOS rows below due to the supergroup in this field. The highest convergences arising from lens groups are in quads. Middle:\u00a0<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn337.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn338.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> for LOS groups with the largest of these values in their field. The quad vs. double distributions cannot be distinguished. Bottom:\u00a0<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn339.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn340.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span> distributions or all groups in the sightline except for the lens group. The shapes of the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn341.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span> distributions are different for quads vs. doubles, but the means are not. In summary, while lens environment is connected to the observed high quad/double ratio, we currently have little evidence for the importance of LOS groups in this context.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f8\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f8\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>In future large surveys, scant resources may be available for the deep surveys that would be necessary to create a full group catalog like we use here. Photometric redshifts of sufficient quality to identify peaks in the LOS redshift distribution that indicate possible clusters and large groups likely will be available, however. So, we investigate whether prioritizing spectroscopic followup of the most significant LOS group would capture most of the LOS contribution from groups.</p><p>Ideally, a lens field would have extensive spectroscopic followup which could be used to identify and characterize all the LOS groups rather than just the most significant one. So, we also investigate the full LOS group distribution. We test how significant the LOS groups are as well as look for fields with a significant total LOS contribution but without any individually significant groups.</p><p>Although groups with larger convergences typically also have larger shears, there is some scatter in the relation. Thus, the group with the largest convergence is not necessarily that with the largest shear. In only one field of our 21 field subset is the LOS group with the largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn342.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> not also the LOS group with the largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn343.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>.</p><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s6-1\" name=\"apjaa9653s6-1\">6.1.\u00a0Convergence</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We look for LOS groups with the largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn344.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> in their fields that are individually significant (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn345.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups, see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t3\">3</a>). There are 12 fields with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn346.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span> including the 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainty. Two fields have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn347.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>.</p><p>We then calculate the contribution of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn348.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn349.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> for fields with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn350.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span> (see Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f5\">5</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f6\">6</a>). As was the case for lens groups (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s5-1\">5.1</a>), the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn351.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups span a large range of contributions to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn352.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>. However, in fields with lenses the lens groups' distribution has a mean value of 25% of the total, while that for the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn353.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups has a mean of 53%; an MWW test is significant. In eight of 12 fields with lens groups (67%), the fraction of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn354.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> contributed by the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn355.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> group is greater than twice that contributed by the lens group. We perform a bootstrap means comparison (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653app2\">B</a>). The resulting mean for the lens groups' fraction of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn356.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> distribution is as large as, or larger than, that for the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn357.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups in 0.3% of trials. The mean of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn358.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups fraction of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn359.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> distribution is at least as small as the measured value for lens groups &lt;0.1% of the time. So the means of these distributions are significantly different.</p><p>Thus lens groups, when present, often are not the most important single group in their fields. This result agrees with our finding in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s5-1\">5.1</a> that lens groups often are not the only important group-scale contributor.</p><p>We compare the properties of lens groups and the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn360.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups. Eight out of 12 (67%) of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn361.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups are in the foreground of the lenses. The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn362.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups and lens groups do not have mean redshifts distinguishable at \u226595% confidence level in a t-test, however. This result indicates the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn363.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> groups are not at significantly lower redshifts where they might be better sampled in our data.
