The mean <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn364.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> group velocity dispersion is significantly larger than those of lens groups using a t-test. Although galaxy clusters are uncommon, these sightlines probe a large volume. Clusters are also more common at lower redshifts where we have few lens galaxies.</p><p>Next, we calculate the convergence due to all LOS groups (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn365.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span>). Thirteen fields are consistent with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn366.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>, and three fields are consistent with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn367.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>, considering the 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties. The fractional contribution of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn368.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span> to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn369.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> is shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f5\">5</a> and, for just fields with lens groups, Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f6\">6</a>. The mean of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn370.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> distribution for fields with lens groups (75%) is larger than that of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn371.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{lens}}/{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> (25%). The distributions are distinguishable using an MWW test. Again, we perform a bootstrap means comparison. The resulting mean for the lens groups' fraction of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn372.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> distribution is as large or larger than that for the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn373.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span> groups &lt;0.1% of the time, and the mean of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn374.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span> fraction of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn375.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> distribution is at least as small as the measured value for lens groups &lt;0.1% of the time. So the means of these distributions also are significantly different.</p><p>All of our fields have multiple groups identified. If a field has enough groups, fields without any that are significant by themselves could nonetheless have a significant <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn376.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> due to the combination of multiple individually insignificant groups. Of those fields without either a lens or LOS group with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn377.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span> considering the 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties, one has a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn378.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>. One field has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn379.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>, despite not having any individual groups meeting this criterion. These results show it is possible for multiple insignificant groups to add up to a significant total contribution, although the dominant mode is for a significant overall contribution to be driven by at least one individually significant group. Our analysis throughout this paper only provides a lower limit to how frequently the former mode occurs, however (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s3\">3</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s6-2\" name=\"apjaa9653s6-2\">6.2.\u00a0Shear</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>There are 14 fields where the LOS group with largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn380.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn381.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span>) is consistent with being greater than 0.01 considering the 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t3\">3</a>). One field has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn382.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> greater than 0.05.</p><p>Again, we look at the shear contribution due to all LOS groups (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn383.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span>). Sixteen fields have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn384.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>, and none has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn385.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>, considering the 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties.</p><p>As for the convergence, we look for fields without an individually significant group that nevertheless has a significant total shear. Of those groups without either a lens or LOS group with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn386.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span> considering the 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties, four have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn387.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>. One field has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn388.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>, considering the uncertainties, despite not having any individual groups meeting this criterion. These results support those for the convergence that sometimes, but not often, a field can have an overall shear due to groups that is significant without having any individually significant groups.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaa9653s6-3\" name=\"apjaa9653s6-3\">6.3.\u00a0LOS Structures of Quads versus Doubles</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Since LOS structures are important to our fields as a whole, we now test whether these structures affect the quad/double ratio, as the lens environments did in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s5-3\">5.3</a>.</p><p>First, we consider the quad versus double distributions of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn389.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span>, which includes all structures along the sightline except for at the lens (left bottom panel; Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f8\">8</a>). A K-S test excludes the possibility that the quad and double distributions are drawn from the same distribution at the &gt;95% level. However, a bootstrap means comparison test (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653app2\">B</a>) does not distinguish the means.</p><p>Next, we compare the LOS groups with the largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn390.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> (left middle panel; Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f8\">8</a>) in the quads versus double fields. The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn391.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> distributions of these groups in the fields of quads and doubles are not distinguishable using a K-S test, nor are their means using a bootstrap means comparison.</p><p>For completeness, we also consider the shear distributions for the LOS groups with the largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn392.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn393.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span>), and the full LOS (right middle and right bottom panels; Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f8\">8</a>). Neither the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn394.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los}}</script></span></span> nor the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn395.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> quad versus double distributions are distinguishable using K-S test or a bootstrap means comparison.</p><p>These results agrees with those of Collett &amp; Cunnington (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib19\">2016</a>), who find a only a small bias (a 0.009 shift in the LOS convergence expectation value) in LOS properties of quad sightlines when the lens environment is excluded.</p><p>In summary, while some LOS groups can be more important to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn396.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> than the lens group (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s6-1\">6.1</a>), quad lenses are more often in groups than doubles (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s5-3\">5.3</a>) and those quad groups can produce larger <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn397.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> values (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f8\">8</a>). These two results together suggest that the local lens environment plays a significant role in driving the quad/double ratio. Any additional role of the LOS in increasing the quad/double ratio remains unclear.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653s7\" name=\"apjaa9653s7\">7.\u00a0Implications for <em>H</em><sub>0</sub></h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>To summarize, at least five of 22 (23%) of our systems with firm spectroscopic lens redshifts (including b0712) have lens groups with effective convergences that affect the lensing potential at the \u22651% level or greater (assuming the lens galaxy's convergence is ~1; see, e.g., Keeton &amp; Zabludoff <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib52\">2004</a>). Twelve of 21 (57%) of our fields with firm lens spectroscopic redshifts and no supergroup have at least one LOS group not at the lens redshift that contributes at the \u22651% level. The dominant contributor to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn398.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> for fields with both a significant <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn399.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and a lens group is more frequently a LOS group than a lens group. Considering all groups, 15 of 21 (71%) fields have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn400.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> that will affect time-delay lens measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> at the \u22651% level.</p><p>Often modelers assume that the lens galaxy and the lens environment are the only two important contributors to the lensing potential. Our results indicate that, while the lens environment can be important, in a substantial fraction of systems there also is significant LOS structure. Thus, if either lens groups or LOS groups are neglected, there could be significant systematic bias (an overestimate, since <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn401.gif\" alt=\"$h\\propto (1-\\kappa )$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">h\\propto (1-\\kappa )</script></span></span>; see Keeton &amp; Zabludoff <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib52\">2004</a>) in the derived <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> if 1% accuracy is the goal.</p><p>As it will be observationally expensive to perform deep spectroscopic surveys in all of the several thousand lens fields LSST is expected to find, an alternative method to account for group-scale perturbations would be to statistically correct the derived <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> given some average convergence. This general approach of calibrating a lensing parameter is already being used; Rusu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib102\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib102\">2017</a>) use sightlines through simulations that are similar to observed lens sightlines to constrain the external convergence of individual lens systems, for example. Here, we calculate the average convergences of the nine time-delay lens systems in our sample. If the convergences from lens environments and LOS groups are ignored, the resulting <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> would be overestimated by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn402.gif\" alt=\"${11}_{-2}^{+3}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{11}_{-2}^{+3}</script></span></span>% on average. If only LOS groups are ignored, then <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> would be overestimated by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn403.gif\" alt=\"${7}_{-2}^{+3}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{7}_{-2}^{+3}</script></span></span>%. This calibration will improve with larger and thus more representative samples.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653s8\" name=\"apjaa9653s8\">8.\u00a0Calibrating the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn404.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}</script></span></span>\u2212<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn405.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{{\\rm{tot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{tot}}}</script></span></span> Relation</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Although <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn406.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> can be inferred from lens models of measured image separations, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn407.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> is unconstrained because of the mass sheet degeneracy. However, neglecting the contributions of lens environment and LOS structures to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn408.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> can bias derived parameters, such as <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> (as discussed in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s7\">7</a>) and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn409.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}</script></span></span> (Keeton &amp; Zabludoff <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib52\">2004</a>). Here we compare the measured <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn410.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> to the measured <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn411.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> from our fields to quantify their relationship and to estimate how predictive a lens-model-derived <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn412.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> might be of that system's <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn413.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>.</p><p>We calculate both <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn414.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn415.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> for each of our lens fields using our group catalog. We note that our dynamical measure of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn416.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> can differ from that derived via lens modeling of image separations (see Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib132\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib132\">2011</a>). Our shear is by definition large-scale. If there is any small-scale shear due to the structure of the main lens galaxy itself (e.g., a misalignment of the stellar and dark matter components, dark matter substructure, or baryonic structures) it would be reflected in the lens-modeling-derived shear but not our calculation of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn417.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>. However, our values agree within the uncertainties for three of the four systems for which lens-derived measurements are available in the literature (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s4\">4</a>).</p><p>There should be a physical relation between shear and convergence, since they both arise from the mass distribution. Being able to estimate convergence from the shear inferred from lens models, perhaps with some adjustments from photometric observables like galaxy number density (e.g., Suyu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib110\">2013</a>), could help select \"golden lenses,\" i.e., low-convergence systems, from a large lens sample, thus prioritizing the more laborious spectroscopic followup. Here we use our measurements to calibrate directly the relation between <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn418.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn419.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{{\\rm{tot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{tot}}}</script></span></span>.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f9\">9</a> we plot <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn420.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn421.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> for our fields and fit a power law to the relation. We find the geometrical mean of the two-sided error bars on <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn422.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn423.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>, which were calculated from the uncertainties in measured group properties using the bootstrap method (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s3\">3</a>). The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn424.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }^{2}</script></span></span> fit using the resulting uncertainties, and the uncertainties in the slope and intercept, is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn425.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}})=(1.94\\pm 0.34)\\mathrm{log}({\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}})+(1.31\\pm 0.49)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}})=(1.94\\pm 0.34)\\mathrm{log}({\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}})+(1.31\\pm 0.49)</script></span></span>. The root mean square error is 0.34 dex. The linear Pearson correlation coefficient of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn426.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}})</script></span></span> versus <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn427.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}({\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}({\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}})</script></span></span> is 0.77.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f9_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 9.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f9_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0\n<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn428.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> vs. <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn429.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> for our 21 field subsample. Error bars denote the 16th and 84th percentiles on our 1000 bootstrap iterations of our group catalog. The black dashed line (<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn430.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}})=(1.94\\pm 0.34)\\mathrm{log}({\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}})+(1.31\\pm 0.49)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}})=(1.94\\pm 0.34)\\mathrm{log}({\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}})+(1.31\\pm 0.49)</script></span></span>) is a <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn431.gif\" alt=\"${\\chi }^{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\chi }^{2}</script></span></span> fit including the geometric means of the two-sided error bars in both <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn432.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn433.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>. A small shear does not necessarily imply the field also has a small convergence, but a large shear generally implies a large convergence; four of the 21 fields (19%) have <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn434.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\gt 2{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\gt 2{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f9\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f9\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The slope of the relation is steeper than <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn435.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa =\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa =\\gamma</script></span></span>. This slope is affected by the shape of the assumed density profiles of the individual group halos. At small shears and convergences, the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn436.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{{\\rm{eff}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{eff}}}</script></span></span> of individual halos tends to be larger than <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn437.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{eff}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{eff}}}</script></span></span> for NFW halos. This relation between the individual halo values approaches <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn438.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa =\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa =\\gamma</script></span></span> then becomes more steep at large convergence and shear because of the shape of the inner regions of NFW halos (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653app3\">C</a> and Oguri et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib91\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib91\">2005</a>). These values are combined differently to calculate <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn439.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn440.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}};$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}};</script></span></span> convergences simply add, but shears add as tensors. As groups' contributions are added up, convergences always increase, but shears can increase or decrease depending on the groups' relative positions on the sky. As the strength of the contribution from multiple LOS perturbers increases, fields consequently are pushed to the upper left of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn441.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa =\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa =\\gamma</script></span></span> relation. If a field's large convergence and shear is due to a single structure, then the total field values do not necessarily move above the relation. Fields with few and/or very insignificant groups may remain below the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn442.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa =\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa =\\gamma</script></span></span> relation if the sum of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn443.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{eff}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{eff}}}</script></span></span> is not enough to overcome their initial deficit compared to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn444.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{{\\rm{eff}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{eff}}}</script></span></span>.</p><p>Recently, investigators have used a combination of galaxy counts and cosmological simulations to constrain <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn445.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>. For example, Suyu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib110\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib110\">2013</a>) calculate the galaxy counts, external shears, and convergences in 64 simulated sightlines in the Millennium Simulation and then select the sightlines that best match the observed lens sightline to constrain the likely value of convergence external to the main galaxy lens. Greene et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib34\">2013</a>) and Rusu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib102\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib102\">2017</a>) use a similar technique but with weighted number counts as well as external shear in the latter study.</p><p>Does incorporating the normalized galaxy number density along the sightline to reduce the scatter in our <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn446.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{tot}}}</script></span></span> versus <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn447.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{{\\rm{tot}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{{\\rm{tot}}}</script></span></span> relation? We would expect lens LOSs to have larger overdensities, since most lens galaxies are massive galaxies that preferentially reside in higher-density environments (e.g., Hilbert et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib37\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib37\">2007</a>; Fassnacht et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib27\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib27\">2011</a>). To calculate this overdensity, or normalized galaxy number density (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn448.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}</script></span></span>), we divide the number of galaxies in our photometry with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn449.gif\" alt=\"$I\\lt 21.5$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">I\\lt 21.5</script></span></span> mag within <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn450.gif\" alt=\"${2}^{{\\prime} }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{2}^{{\\prime} }</script></span></span> of the lens by the median number of such galaxies in random sightlines chosen in the following way in the same field.</p><p>We examine all the objects, stars as well as galaxies, in the photometric fields to mask out regions that could have depressed galaxy counts, including blank regions from non-operational CCDs, obvious chip gaps due to inadequately dithered exposures, and regions near bright stars. We mask out the lens sightlines when selecting random sightlines. We include only random sightlines that lie completely within the well-sampled field. We discard random sightlines that overlap the masked regions until we have 1000 acceptable sightlines per field.</p><p>We calculate the partial correlation coefficient of log(<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn451.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>) versus log(<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn452.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>) removing the effects of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn453.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}</script></span></span>. The value, 0.77, is the same as without considering <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn454.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}</script></span></span>. There is also no significant correlation between the offset of a field from the best-fit line and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn455.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}</script></span></span>. Thus, it is not obvious that incorporating the normalized galaxy number density improves our correlation.</p><p>Overall, the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn456.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> does not always predict <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn457.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> well. Four of 21 fields (19%) have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn458.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>; all have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn459.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}},{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\gt $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}},{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\gt</script></span></span> 0.01. The <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn460.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> inferred directly from <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn461.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> will thus be underestimated by \u22650.01, leading to a \u22651% bias in <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>. Our <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn462.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn463.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> measurements have large uncertainties, so how far a field might actually be off the relation is uncertain. However, in our bootstrap iterations of our group catalog, 16% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn464.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>, and 0.5% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn465.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 10</script></span></span>.</p><p>If only the lens group contribution to the shear is known, one should be especially cautious of using this shear to predict the field's <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn466.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>. For our measured groups, 10 of 12 fields with lens groups (83%) have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn467.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>. One of 12 (8%) has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn468.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 10</script></span></span>. In our bootstrap iterations, 63% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn469.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>, and 17% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn470.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 10</script></span></span>.</p><p>The shear of the LOS group with the largest shear is better at predicting the field's <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn471.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>. For our measured groups, 5 of 21 fields (24%) have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn472.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>. One of 21 (5%) has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn473.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 10</script></span></span>. In our bootstrap iterations, 25% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn474.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>, and 3% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn475.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }\\geqslant 10</script></span></span>.</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f10\">10</a> illustrates how many groups are significant contributors to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn476.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn477.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>, as well as how adding each group affects <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn478.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn479.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>. We sort the groups within a field from largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn480.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> to smallest and calculate <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn481.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn482.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> after adding each group one at a time. We plot the resulting tracks in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f10\">10</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f10\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f10\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f10_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 10.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 10.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f10_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 10.</strong>\u00a0Build-up of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn483.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn484.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> from individual groups for each lens beam. Each colored track represents an individual field. The cross indicates the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn485.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn486.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> of the group with the largest <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn487.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> in that field. Each connected dot represents the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn488.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn489.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> each time a group with the next smallest <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn490.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> is added. The <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn491.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn492.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> with all groups in the field included is marked with an open circle. There is a diversity of ways of reaching a field's total values depending on how many comparably significant groups there are and their relative position angles on the sky.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f10\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f10\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>There is a diversity of tracks. As is also evident in Figures <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f2\">2</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f3\">3</a>, some fields have one group that dominates, others have one or two that are of similar importance, and others have several significant groups. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f3\">3</a> illustrated how the distribution of groups on the sky in our fields can affect <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn493.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> as well.
