Some fields' groups with the largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn494.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> have similar <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn495.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn496.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> but end up with total field values that are in different parts of the plot (e.g., the magenta, green, and light blue fields in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f10\">10</a>). Other fields have total values that are similar but have groups with the largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn497.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn498.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn499.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{los},\\max }</script></span></span> that were different (e.g., the gray and purple fields near the top of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f10\">10</a>).</p><p>From this analysis, the scatter and best-fit relation of log(<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn500.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>) and log(<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn501.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span>) appear to be driven by the number of groups and their relative placement on the sky. Two fields can have similar <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn502.gif\" alt=\"${N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{N}_{{\\rm{gal}},{\\rm{norm}}}</script></span></span> but very different <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn503.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> because the two most important groups are oriented differently on the sky (~90\u00b0 apart around the lens instead of ~180\u00b0 or 0\u00b0 apart) or because the galaxies are mostly in one group (which then dominates the lensing perturbation) rather than split into many (which can have canceling <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn504.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>).</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653s9\" name=\"apjaa9653s9\">9.\u00a0Conclusions</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Cosmological constraints on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from strong gravitational lensing measurements now aim for percent or even sub-percent precision, a goal directly depending on the uncertainty in the convergence (<em>\u03ba</em>). Unlike shear (<em>\u03b3</em>), <em>\u03ba</em> is not directly measured by lensing observations, only inferred from assumptions about the mass distribution. Here we use kinematic measurements of the mass distribution of the lens environment and along the line-of-sight (LOS) to constrain <em>\u03ba</em> directly, quantifying how much ignoring the contributions of lens environment and LOS structures might bias <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> determinations. We also determine <em>\u03b3</em> from our kinematic measurements, quantifying the effects on <em>\u03b3</em> due to lens environment and the LOS and comparing them to the precision of current <em>\u03b3</em> measurements from lens imaging. Since shears enter the lens equation as <em>\u03b3</em> multiplied by the uncertainty in lens image position (typically <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn505.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 003$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 003</script></span></span>; Courbin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib22\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib22\">1997</a>), shears of 0.01 lead to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn506.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 3\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 3\\sigma</script></span></span> effects. We also evaluate the usefulness of <em>\u03b3</em> as a predictor of <em>\u03ba</em>.</p><p>To test these effects on <em>\u03ba</em> and thus on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, we consider two significance thresholds: <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn507.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa \\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa \\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span> and 0.05. The former is consistent with the percent target on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> (LSST Dark Energy Science Collaboration <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib66\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib66\">2012</a>); the latter is the approximate level of current discrepancies among <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> determinations from different methods (e.g., Riess et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib101\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib101\">2011</a>; Bennett et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib7\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib7\">2014</a>; Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib97\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib97\">2016</a>; Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib133\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib133\">2017</a>). We consider the same thresholds for assessing significant lens environment or LOS contributions to <em>\u03b3</em>, given that shears of \u22650.01 correspond to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn508.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 3\\sigma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 3\\sigma</script></span></span> effects compared with the observed image position uncertainties, making heretofore ignored contributions at the &gt;0.01 level problematic.</p><p>In Wilson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>), we identified massive groups around the lens galaxy and along the sightline in the fields of 26 strong lensing galaxies. Here, we assess the significance of those lens' environments and LOSs in our cleanest 21 fields.</p><p>Our main results are as follows.</p><ul>\n<li>The total convergence due to any group at the lens and along the sightline ranges from <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn509.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\lt 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\lt 0.01</script></span></span> to 0.24. The total shear <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn510.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> ranges from &lt;0.01 to 0.11.</li>\n<li>Lens groups are often important: five of 22 (23%) have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn511.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>, and three (14%) have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn512.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>. Considering shear, eight (36%) have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn513.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>, and three (14%) have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn514.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>.</li>\n<li>LOS groups (not at the lens redshift) are also often important. In 12 of 21 fields (57%), there is at least one LOS group with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn515.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\gt 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\gt 0.01</script></span></span>, and 2 (10%) have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn516.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>. Fourteen fields (67%) have at least one LOS group with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn517.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>, and 1 (5%) has <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn518.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.05$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}\\geqslant 0.05</script></span></span>.</li>\n<li>LOS groups can be more important than the lens group. In fields with lens groups and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn519.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>, the LOS group with the largest <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn520.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> contributes \u22652<b>&#x00d7;</b> more to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn521.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> than the lens group ~67% of the time.</li>\n<li>Previous studies (e.g., Keeton &amp; Zabludoff <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib52\">2004</a>; Momcheva et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib77\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib77\">2006</a>) suggest that lens environment is connected to the relative numbers of systems with four and two images (the quad/double ratio) and why more quads are observed than expected (Kochanek <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib56\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib56\">1996</a>). All seven of our quad lenses, but only three of 10 doubles, are in groups, a statistically significant difference. There is a population of quad lens groups with large <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn522.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> that has no counterpart for doubles. Thus, lens groups are important for the quad/double ratio. The effects of the LOS structures are not as obvious: we do not find a statistically significant difference between the LOS convergences for quads versus doubles.</li>\n<li>Without proper calibration, shear can be a poor predictor of convergence. The correlation is significant with the form <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn523.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{log}({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}})=(1.94\\pm 0.34)\\mathrm{log}({\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}})+(1.31\\pm 0.49)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{log}({\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}})=(1.94\\pm 0.34)\\mathrm{log}({\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}})+(1.31\\pm 0.49)</script></span></span> with a rms scatter of 0.34 dex. <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn524.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> underestimates <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn525.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn526.gif\" alt=\"$\\geqslant 2\\times $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\geqslant 2\\times</script></span></span> for four of 21 (19%) of our fields. If <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn527.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span>, then the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn528.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> inferred directly from <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn529.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> would be underestimated by \u22650.01, leading to a \u22651% bias in <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>. The offset from our best fit <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn530.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> vs. <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn531.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> relation is not well-correlated with lens sightline galaxy number density, suggesting that it is difficult to simply correct <em>\u03b3</em> by galaxy density to get <em>\u03ba</em>.</li>\n</ul><p>\n</p><p>In summary, groups contribute significantly to the convergence in 15 of the 21 fields here. These groups can be in the lens environment and/or along the LOS. For four fields, the lens group alone is significant. For 10 fields without a significant lens group, an LOS group alone is significant. For one field, several individually insignificant groups add to contribute a significant total convergence.</p><p>Groups contribute significantly to the shear in 18 of the 21 fields analyzed. For seven fields, the lens group alone is significant. For nine fields without a significant lens group, an LOS group alone is significant. For four fields, several individually insignificant groups add to contribute a significant total shear. For two fields, the total shear is not significant although an individual group's shear is because the shears of multiple groups cancel, as shears add as tensors. These shears due to groups will affect overall shear measurements comparably or more than the 3<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainties in measured image positions.</p><p>To use galaxy-scale gravitationally lensed systems to determine cosmological parameters to the <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" />1% level\u2014an LSST goal\u2014it is critical to characterize and/or correct for both lens environments and LOS structures. For example, if the nine time-delay lens systems in our sample are representative of those used in ensemble <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> calculations, <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is overestimated by <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn532.gif\" alt=\"${11}_{-2}^{+3}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{11}_{-2}^{+3}</script></span></span>% on average if both LOS and the local lens environment are ignored. If only the LOS contribution is ignored, then the <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> bias is <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn533.gif\" alt=\"${7}_{-2}^{+3}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{7}_{-2}^{+3}</script></span></span>%. Future surveys including volume-limited lens samples will reveal how general these results are.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We thank the anonymous referee for helpful comments. M.L.W. and A.I.Z. acknowledge support from NSF grant AST-1211874. M.L.W. also thanks the Technology and Research Initiative Fund (TRIF) Imaging Fellowship program for its support. C.R.K. acknowledges support from NSF grant AST-1211385. K.C.W. is supported by an EACOA Fellowship awarded by the East Asia Core Observatories Association, which consists of the Academia Sinica Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan, the National Astronomical Observatories of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and the Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute.</p><p><em>Facilities:</em> Mayall (Mosaic-I) - ,  Blanco (Mosaic-II) - ,  Magellan-1 (LDSS-2 - ,  LDSS-3) - ,  Magellan-2 (IMACS) - ,  MMT (Hectospec) - .</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653app1\" name=\"apjaa9653app1\">Appendix A: Lens System References</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Here we present the references for the discoveries and lens and source redshifts for the systems in our sample (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaa9653t4\">4</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjaa9653t4\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 4.</b>\u00a0\nLens System References\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653t4\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t4_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 4\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Field</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Official Lens Name</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Lens Discovery</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>z</em><sub>L</sub> Reference</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>z</em><sub>S</sub> Reference</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">b0712</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">CLASS B0712+472</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Jackson et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib14\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib14\">1997</a>); Auger et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib3\">2008</a>)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Momcheva et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib78\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib78\">2015</a>)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">wfi2033</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">WFI J2033\u22124723</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Morgan et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib81\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib81\">2004</a>)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Eigenbrod et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib25\">2006</a>)</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Momcheva et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib78\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib78\">2015</a>)</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjaa9653t4fna\" id=\"apjaa9653t4fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/castles/\">https://www.cfa.harvard.edu/castles/</a>\n\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t4_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa9653\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/suppdata/apjaa9653t4_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653app2\" name=\"apjaa9653app2\">Appendix B: Bootstrap Means Comparison</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We would like to compare the mean values of several distributions in this work that are obviously non-Gaussian. We therefore perform the following bootstrap method-based test.</p><p>Consider two distributions, <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, where the number of samples in <em>A</em> (<em>N</em><sub><em>A</em></sub>) is larger than the number of samples in <em>B</em> (<em>N</em><sub><em>B</em></sub>). We randomly select <em>N</em><sub><em>B</em></sub> values from distribution <em>A</em> for 1000 trials. We then find the fraction of trials in which the resulting mean values are at least as extreme as distribution <em>B</em>'s measured mean. For example, if <em>B</em>'s measured mean is greater than the measured mean of <em>A</em>, we thus calculate the fraction of trials that result in means at least as large.</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaa9653app3\" name=\"apjaa9653app3\">Appendix C: Truncation Radius Choice</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>What group halo mass profile we assume, i.e., where or if we truncate it, could affect our results. There is certainly mass associated with groups outside <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn534.gif\" alt=\"$1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}</script></span></span>. Urban et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib120\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib120\">2014</a>) detect the Perseus cluster's intracluster medium beyond the virial radius in five of the eight radial directions they probe. Bah\u00e9 et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib5\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib5\">2013</a>) and Zinger et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib136\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib136\">2016</a>) have found cluster hot gas halos to extend beyond <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn535.gif\" alt=\"$1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}</script></span></span> (to at least 5<em>r</em><sub>200</sub> and to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn536.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 2\\mbox{--}3{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 2\\mbox{--}3{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}</script></span></span>, respectively). Bah\u00e9 et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib5\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib5\">2013</a>), in their simulations, identify galaxies that are bound to the group and mostly have passed within <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn537.gif\" alt=\"$1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}</script></span></span> but are on orbits with apocenters out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn538.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 3{r}_{200}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 3{r}_{200}</script></span></span>, which motivated us in part to accept group members out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn539.gif\" alt=\"$3{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">3{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}</script></span></span> (Wilson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib128\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib128\">2016</a>).</p><p>The splashback radius is another possible halo edge definition. This radius is where there is a steepening in the halo density profile due to a pileup of the apocenters of the matter that has been most recently accreted. Adhikari et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib1\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib1\">2014</a>), using an analytical toy model, predict this radius to be ~0.8\u20131<em>r</em><sub>200<em>m</em></sub> but found that it depends on accretion rate and redshift. More et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib79\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib79\">2015</a>), using simulations, also find that this radius depends on halo accretion rate but is typically around 0.8-1.5<em>r</em><sub>200<em>m</em></sub>. In another refinement, Mansfield et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib70\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib70\">2017</a>) develop an algorithm to identify splashback shells that allows for asphericity. They find slightly larger radii for halos with higher mass accretion rates and an overall splashback radius range of ~1\u20131.6<em>r</em><sub>200<em>m</em></sub>. Observations suggest slightly smaller than expected splashback radii. For example, More et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib80\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib80\">2016</a>) calculate splashback radii of ~0.6\u20131<em>r</em><sub>200<em>m</em></sub> in their study of galaxy number densities around SDSS clusters.</p><p>It is unclear how well an NFW profile describes the outskirts. NFW profiles were developed from virialized halos in simulations (Navarro et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib88\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib88\">1997</a>); our groups might not all be relaxed (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s3\">3</a>). Outer cluster halos in simulations and some observations often have complex structures and are not always described well by NFW profiles. For example, in their X-ray study of the Perseus cluster, Urban et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib120\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib120\">2014</a>) find azimuthal variations and departures from expectations from numerical simulations; at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn540.gif\" alt=\"$r\\gt 0.4{r}_{200}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">r\\gt 0.4{r}_{200}</script></span></span>, the average density profile's power law index is significantly smaller than predicted as well as there being differences in the entropy and pressure profiles. They attribute these differences to gas being clumpy instead of smoothly distributed as models approximate. However, the weak lensing analysis of Umetsu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib118\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib118\">2011</a>) find that, for the four of their five clusters not undergoing mergers, an untruncated NFW profile is consistent with their lensing measurements over their fields, which extend out to 1.2\u20131.7<em>r</em><sub>200</sub>. Umetsu &amp; Diemer (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib119\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib119\">2017</a>), using combined strong and weak lensing, find that NFW profiles adequately describe the profiles of 16 Cluster Lensing and Supernova survey with Hubble clusters out to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn541.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 2.5\\,{h}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 2.5\\,{h}^{-1}</script></span></span> Mpc (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn542.gif\" alt=\"$\\sim 1.2{r}_{200{\\rm{m}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sim 1.2{r}_{200{\\rm{m}}}</script></span></span>), outside of which the profile flattens. In addition, the above simulations and observations mostly focus on cluster-sized halos, not the groups that make up most of our catalog.</p><p>As there is some ambiguity as to how to describe the mass outside <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn543.gif\" alt=\"$1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">1{r}_{\\mathrm{vir}}</script></span></span> for our groups and to the best description of the halo edge, we conservatively choose a truncation radius of 1r<sub>200m</sub> for our main analyses.</p><p>We recalculate <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn544.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn545.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> using untruncated NFW profiles to see how this choice affects our results (see Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaa9653f11\">11</a>).</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaa9653f11\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaa9653f11\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f11_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 11.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 11.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653f11_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 11.</strong>\u00a0Effective convergences and shears for all the groups in our catalog in fields other than h12531 (since this field has no source redshift estimate). Black filled circles are values using NFW profiles truncated at <em>r</em><sub>200<em>m</em></sub>, and red open circles are those using untruncated NFW profiles. Gray error bars represent the 16th to 84th percentile ranges on the <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn546.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn547.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}</script></span></span> values considering the uncertainties on the measured group properties. The colored curves are the shears and convergences calculated with GRAVLENS (Keeton <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib47\">2001</a>) for untruncated NFW profiles at a range of projected separations from the lens for three values of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn548.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{s}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{s}}}</script></span></span> (0.03, 0.1, and 0.3 in green, cyan, and blue, respectively). A dotted <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn549.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa =\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa =\\gamma</script></span></span> line is included for reference. Truncating the halo results in smaller <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn550.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> values relative to <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn551.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>. However, at larger values of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn552.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}},{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}},{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>, <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn553.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> grows quicker than <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn554.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> as separations from the lens decrease, so the relation converges to <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn555.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa =\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa =\\gamma</script></span></span>. Some of the scatter for a given truncation choice, especially at large values, is due to the range of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn556.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{{\\rm{s}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{{\\rm{s}}}</script></span></span> for our groups.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaa9653f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadFigure/figure/apjaa9653f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaa9653f11\" href=\"/0004-637X/850/1/94/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaa9653f11\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>For either truncation choice, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn557.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> is smaller than <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn558.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> at low values, although in general groups with higher <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn559.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> also have higher <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn560.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>. Convergence is a local quantity and depends on the projected mass surface density at the projected separation of the perturber's center from the main lens. Shear, however, is a large-scale quantity that depends on the total projected enclosed mass as well as projected distance from the lens. For a group projected much farther from the lens than the truncation radius, the mass surface density of the group halo projected directly in front of the lens will be quite small, so <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn561.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> will be very small. <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn562.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> will also be small; however, it will not be as small as <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn563.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>, because the total projected enclosed mass does not get smaller with increasing distance from the group center like mass surface density does. In the extreme case of a point mass projected at some distance from the lens, the convergence would be zero but the shear would be nonzero.</p><p>At high <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn564.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn565.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn566.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> versus <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn567.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> is closer to a <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn568.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa =\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa =\\gamma</script></span></span> relation. In the inner part of NFW halos, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn569.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> diverges logarithmically while <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn570.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> converges to a constant. So, as a halo is projected increasingly closer to the lens, the convergence grows more rapidly than the shear. Thus, the convergence and shear can approach and pass the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn571.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa =\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa =\\gamma</script></span></span> relation at very small projected distances from the lens. However, it is unlikely for a group to be projected exactly in front of the lens, so few of our groups lie above the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn572.gif\" alt=\"$\\kappa =\\gamma $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\kappa =\\gamma</script></span></span> line.</p><p>Generally, the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn573.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff}}</script></span></span> for our groups using NFW halos truncated at <em>r</em><sub>200<em>m</em></sub> agree with those calculated using untruncated NFW profiles at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn574.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{untruncated}}\\gtrsim 0.002$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{untruncated}}\\gtrsim 0.002</script></span></span>, and with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn575.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{untruncated}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{untruncated}}</script></span></span> values for the whole measured range, within the uncertainties in the values calculated using the truncated halos due to uncertainties in the measured group properties (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaa9653s3\">3</a> for a description of our uncertainty estimation). So which, if any, truncation radius we choose should not affect our results much more than the uncertainties in the group properties, although those uncertainties are random and these due to the truncation radius are systematic. Those groups with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn576.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn577.gif\" alt=\"${\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}\\geqslant 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}\\geqslant 0.01</script></span></span> underestimate the untruncated values by a median fractional error of 24% and 3%, respectively; those with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn578.gif\" alt=\"$0.001\\leqslant {\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}\\lt 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.001\\leqslant {\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}\\lt 0.01</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn579.gif\" alt=\"$0.001\\leqslant {\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}\\lt 0.01$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.001\\leqslant {\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{truncated}}\\lt 0.01</script></span></span> have a median fractional error of 59% and 22%, respectively.</p><p>We repeat the main tests in our analysis as well. The quantitative results agree with each other within the uncertainties and do not affect our overall qualitative conclusions except in the following cases.</p><p>A larger fraction, 10 of 21 rather than 5 of 21, of our fields have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn580.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>. This still supports our result that the LOS group with the largest shear is a better predictor of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn581.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}</script></span></span> than the lens group, but it is not as good a predictor as when truncated halos are used.</p><p>In the bootstrap realizations of the group catalog, slightly different fractions of the sample are found to have large differences between <em>\u03ba</em> and <em>\u03b3</em>. With untruncated halos, 24% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn582.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>, and 0.8% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn583.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{tot}}\\geqslant 10</script></span></span>; 72% <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn584.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>, and 19% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn585.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{lens}}\\geqslant 10</script></span></span>; 40% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn586.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 2$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 2</script></span></span>, and 4% have <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/850/1/94/Full/apjaa9653ieqn587.gif\" alt=\"${\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 10$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\kappa }_{\\mathrm{tot}}/{\\gamma }_{\\mathrm{eff},\\mathrm{los}}\\geqslant 10</script></span></span>. Our qualitative results that <em>\u03ba</em> is not a close predictor of <em>\u03b3</em> is unaffected, however.</p><p>Some of the difference between the values calculated using truncated versus untruncated halos might be reduced by including a void correction like that applied in McCully et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaa9653bib73\" id=\"fnref-apjaa9653bib73\">2017</a>). We do not investigate this issue quantitatively. Since the choice makes little qualitative difference to our main results even without the void correction, it should not significantly impact our results.</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list wd-content-footnotes\">\n\t\t\t\t<li class=\"indices-list\"><div Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.</p></p></div></li></ul>\n\t\t</div>\n\t<!-- End Footnotes -->\t\n<!-- By continuing to use this site you agree to our use of cookies.</small></li>\n                    </ul>\n                </div>\n            </nav>\n            </div>\n        </div> <!-- end wrapper -->\n    </div> <!-- end iopp-footer -->\n</footer>\n<!-- Footer tile ends -->\n<script>\n  var imgBase = \"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img\";\n  /*  Cutting the mustard - http://responsivenews.co.uk/post/18948466399/cutting-the-mustard */\n\n  /* This is the original if statement, from the link above. I have amended it to turn of JS on all IE browsers less than 10.\n\tThis is due to a function in the iop.jquery.toolbar.js line 35/36. Uses .remove which is not native js supported in IE9 or lower */\n  /* if('querySelector' in document \n\t&& 'localStorage' in window\n\t&& 'addEventListener' in window) { */\n\n  /* This is the updated selector, taken from: https://justmarkup.com/log/2015/02/26/cut-the-mustard-revisited/ */\n\tif('visibilityState' in document) {\n\n\t/*! loadJS: load a JS file asynchronously. Licensed MIT */\n\tfunction loadJS( src, cb ){\n\t  \"use strict\";\n\t  var ref = window.document.getElementsByTagName( \"script\" )[ 0 ];\n\t  var script = window.document.createElement( \"script\" );\n\t  script.src = src;\n\t  script.async = true;\n\t  ref.parentNode.insertBefore( script, ref );\n\t  if (cb && typeof(cb) === \"function\") {\n\t\tscript.onload = cb;\n\t  }\n\t  return script;\n\t}\n\n\tloadJS( \"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/js/scripts.min.js\" );\n\n  }\n</script>\n\n<script type=\"text/javascript\">window.NREUM||(NREUM={});NREUM.info={\"errorBeacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"licenseKey\":\"b2bfaae1b6\",\"agent\":\"\",\"beacon\":\"bam-cell.nr-data.net\",\"applicationTime\":719,\"applicationID\":\"723879338\",\"transactionName\":\"NAAHMUBVCENSABFZXg1KLzZiGzF1cU4sfndMDxYVQRsFX14OCl4eDwQcCkdASFpAEw==\",\"queueTime\":0}</script></body>\n</html>", "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017ApJ...850...94W", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "Strong gravitational lensing provides an independent measurement of the Hubble parameter (H <SUB>0</SUB>). One remaining systematic is a bias from the additional mass due to a galaxy group at the lens redshift or along the sightline. We quantify this bias for more than 20 strong lenses that have well-sampled sightline mass distributions, focusing on the convergence \u03ba and shear \u03b3. In 23% of these fields, a lens group contributes \u22651% convergence bias; in 57%, there is a similarly significant line-of-sight group. For the nine time-delay lens systems, H <SUB>0</SUB> is overestimated by {11}<SUB>-2</SUB><SUP>+3</SUP>% on average when groups are ignored. In 67% of fields with total \u03ba \u2265slant 0.01, line-of-sight groups contribute \u2273 2\u00d7 more convergence than do lens groups, indicating that the lens group is not the only important mass. Lens environment affects the ratio of four (quad) to two (double) image systems; all seven quads have lens groups while only 3 of 10 doubles do, and the highest convergences due to lens groups are in quads. We calibrate the \u03b3-\u03ba relation: {log}({\u03ba }<SUB>{tot</SUB>})=(1.94+/- 0.34){log}({\u03b3 }<SUB>{tot</SUB>}) +(1.31+/- 0.49) with an rms scatter of 0.34 dex. Although shear can be measured directly from lensed images, unlike convergence, it can be a poor predictor of convergence; for 19% of our fields, \u03ba is \u2273 2\u03b3 . Thus, accurate cosmology using strong gravitational lenses requires precise measurement and correction for all significant structures in each lens field.", "start_page": "94", "authors": ["Wilson, Michelle L.", "Zabludoff, Ann I.", "Keeton, Charles R.", "Wong, Kenneth C.", "Williams, Kurtis A.", "French, K.
